We tried the error string as the third parameter (generally speaking I put
=
optional parameters at the end of the parameter list), but we had a compile=

error, the details of which I don't remember. That's how we ended up with
=
the error message as the first parameter.

As far as the order of parameter=
s in assertEquals(expected, actual), as I
recall this came from my observat=
ion that the expected value is often quite
short, simple, and easy to read =
while the actual value can come from a
complex expression. I find this:
  a=
ssertEquals(5, result.ofComplexCalculation(withParameters,
andMoreParameter=
s));
easier to read than the reverse. However, tests won't break if you swi=
tch
the order of the parameters, you'll just get confusing error messages i=
f the
assertion fails.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute
